We wanted to answer this! GGU is on the tRNA; it is an anticodon. But it's not used to read the codon chart as the codon chart is for the mRNA codons. The mRNA codon that complements GGU is CCA. In the illustration, CCA is shown on that light green mRNA strand. CCA codes for proline on the chart so the tRNA that binds there brings in proline. We hope that helps; it's important to not use the tRNA anticodons for a mRNA codon chart.
@AmoebaSisters oh that makes sense. So it brings the amino acid that matches the mRNA but has a different anticodon?

Hi there! So at 5:06 - the codon on the mRNA that codes for methionine is AUG. And the tRNA that carries methionine has the anticodon UAC. When using a codon chart to determine the amino acid, you typically use the codon on the mRNA (and not the anticodon) to find the amino acid, unless it specifies otherwise. Hope that helps!

you need protein in your body. the only way to make protein is through protein synthesis. you need DNA to make protien.  the DNA is in a strand, in the nucleus. RNA Polymerase connects complementary bases to the DNA. Combined, this is called messenger (m)RNA, which is then sent out into the cytoplasm to be made into protiens. Then, transfer (t)RNA - which has amino acids (building blocks) on it - attach to the messenger (m)RNA, and transfers its amino acids onto it (using the complementary bases + codons).
